abstract.para: The Beginner's Guide describes different workflows to create packages on &obs;. It covers how to create a basic package from an upstream project, create patches, branching a repository, and more.

article.remark: toms 2017-08-08: Generally, describe some/all use cases additionally with the Web UI?

sect1.title: Target Audience
sect1.para: This document is intented for interested users and developers who want to build packages from source code for different distributions. Basic knowledge of Linux and command line handling is recommended.
sect1.remark: toms 2017-08-03: Add some links to basic tutorials etc.?

sect1.title: Conceptual Overview
sect1.para: Created in 2005, the &obs; (&obsa;) is a generic system to build and distribute packages or images from source code in an automatic, consistent and reproducible way. &obsa; is able to create images and installable packages for a wide range of operating systems (&suse;, Debian, Ubuntu, RedHat, Windows, etc.) and hardware architectures (&x86;, &amd64;, &zseries;, &ppc; etc.).

sect2.title: Package Specification
sect2.para: Creating a package in &obsa; needs a package specification which contains the following information:

formalpara.title: Metadata
formalpara.para: The package name and the description is mandatory. Other data like the version, the license, the upstream URL, and some more are optional.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: Packages depend on other packages to function properly. Requirements are distinguished between build requirements and install requirements. Build requirements are dependencies which are needed before the build process starts in &obsa;. For example, a C++ program needs a C++ compiler. Install requirements are dependencies which are used later when the package is finished and ready to be installed.

formalpara.title: A Package List
formalpara.para: To successfully install and remove a package with all the contents, the package manager needs to know which files and directories belong to which package.

sect2.para: For RPM-based systems like &suse;, all the information above is included in a file with the file extension .spec.
sect2.remark: toms 2017-08-08: Describe other naming conventions which applies only for certain distributions

sect2.title: Build Hosts and Packages
sect2.para: The &obs; can communicate either through a Web interface or a command line interface. Both access the OBS API which controls the database, the search engine, and more. The OBS API communicates also indirectly with the backend which provides a storage pool and the build hosts.

To build the package, the backend creates a sandbox of the respective distribution on demand. This sandbox is isolated from the rest of the host system. Depending on the package specification (the so called spec file on RPM-based systems), other packages are downloaded and installed prior to building.

The build process itself executes all the instructions inside the spec file. If the build was successful, the files which belongs to the package are installed in the sandbox and the final RPM package is created and moved into a download area (the download repository). This makes the package publicly available and can installed with &yast; or zypper.
Other services around &obsa; (like the notification server, mirror interface etc.) has specific purpose which is of less importance for this guide. See for a complete picture.

sect2.title: Projects and Packages
sect2.para: In &obsa;, packages are organized in projects. A single project can contain several different packages and serves a specific purpose, defines access control, other repositories, and build targets (operating systems and architectures).

Projects can also contain other projects (subprojects) to structure work. Each project name is separated by colons. For example, all packages for fonts are collected in the project M17N:fonts and all relevant packages for the Python programming language are available in the devel:languages:python project.

As a user, you will build your packages normally in your home project, available in &obsa; as home:USERNAME. The home project is your working area in OBS for defining build targets, uploading and building packages, and installing the results with Zypper or &yast;.
Sometimes you see the obs://PROJECT notation. The obs:// schema is a shorthand to abbreviate the long URL and needs to be replaced by the real &obsa; instance URL.

sect1.title: Requirements
sect1.para: Before you work with &obs;, make sure you fullfil the following requirements.

listitem.para: To work with &obs; install the &osccmd; command line tool from your preferred distributions or from the &obsa; project openSUSE:Tools. The tool runs on any modern Linux system and is available for different distributions, like CentOS, Debian, SLE, &opensuse;, to name a few.
For &suse; related systems, install it with the zypper command (replace DISTRI with your distribution):
For other systems, use your preferred package manager.

As an alternative, use the &appimg; file. An &appimg; file is a packaged application which can run on many distributions. Download the file, save it in your ~/bin directory, and make the file executable.
Make sure you have a minimum of 1GB of disk space available. The &osccmd; command builds all packages locally under &oscbuildpath; and caches downloaded packages under &oscbuildcache;.

sect1.para: This guide assumes:

sect1.title: Setting Up your Home Project for the First Time
sect1.para: This section shows how you you set up your home project after you have created an &opensuse; account.

When you log in to your home project for the first time, it will be empty naturally. To build your packages you need to select build targets (distributions) first. Build targets are definied globally and appear on every package.
To setup you home project, do the following:

procedure.title: Adding Global Build Targets for Your Home Project

step.para: Log in to the &obs; instance.
Click the Home Project link in the upper right corner.
Click the Repositories tab, then the Add Repositories link.
Select the distributions you want to build for.

&obsa; shows a couple of Linux distributions. For &suse; distributions, it is recommended to choose at least openSUSE Tumbleweed and one of the latest &opensuse; releases. If you like, you can also mark one of the openSUSE Backports for SLE 12 which enables package builds for &sle;.
Whenever you select one of the distributions, &obsa; gives a short notice that it has successfully added it to your home project.
Click the Overview tab to see the the available build targets on the right side.

sect1.para: If you need more build targets you can repeat the procedure above. It will be added to the list of existing build targets.

In case you need to fine tune your build targets, click the Repositories tab, find the respective build target, and click the Edit repository link. This will show the available architectures and additional package repositores you may want to add.

sect1.title: Creating a New Project
sect1.para: This section covers how to create packages from a simple C++ project hosted on &gh; (the upstream project). We assume, this project contains source code which you would like to package for different &suse; distributions. Furthermore, &osccmd; is already installed on your machine.
To create a package from the upstream project, do the following:

step.para: Go to the upstream project at and check the license first. You can only redistribute packages which are available under an open source license. &obsa; checks the license of the source code and will refuse to build packages if the license does not comply with an open source license.
You can find a list of already used licenses in &obsa; at . For more details and a comparison about open source licenses in general, see .
Set up your project as shown in .
Open a shell. Choose or create a directory on your system where you have enough space.
Check out your home project:
This will create home/&obsuser1; in the current directory with the project directory &gitproject; if you have configured &osc; as shown in of .
Create a new package inside your local working directory:
Get the pristine source code of the upstream project and save it in home/&obsuser1;/&gitproject;.
Download the sources from . If the project has not published yet a release, download the latest sources by clicking the Clone or download button and then the Download ZIP link.
Create a spec file which contains metadata and build instructions. For RPM-based distributions like &opensuse;, the basic structure should look like this:
step.remark: toms 2017-08-09: Should the spec file be referenced by a GitHub link? How much detail do we need here?
step.screen:
# # spec file for package &gitproject; # # -- Copyright comitted --
Name: &gitproject; Version: &gitprjvers; Release: 0 License: GPL-3.0 Group: TBD Summary: Example tool for OBS Url: &gitupstream1; Source: &gitproject;-%{version}.tar.gz BuildRequires: gcc BuildRequires: cmake BuildRoot: %{_tmppath}/%{name}-%{version}-build
%description
%prep %setup -q -n %{name}-%{version}
%build
%install
%files %defattr(-,root,root,-) %doc README LICENSE *.txt %{_bindir}/*
%changelog

callout.para: The header with metadata like package name, version, release, license, the RPM group, a brief summary, the upstream URL, and the name of the source file.
Build requirements which are needed by &obsa;. These packages are downloaded and installed before building the package.
The description section. This section is used to illustrate the purpose of the package and gives a comprehensive explanation.

The preparation section. This is used to get the sources ready to build which includes unpacking (using the setup macro). This is also the place when you need to patch your source code using the %patch macro (not shown here).
The build section. This contains Shell commands or RPM macro on how to build the package.
The install section. Contains Shell commands or RPM macro which creates directories or copies files to the installation location.

The files section. This section lists all files and directories which belongs to the package. Documentation related files are marked with %doc and are automatically installed in the default documentation directory (for &suse; it is /usr/share/doc/packages/PACKAGENAME).

The changelog section. Usually this is empty and &obsa; searches for a file with the extension .changes. If such a file exists in the project directory, it will be automatically included as a changelog. The changelog file itself contains a high level overview of the history of the package.

sect1.title: Patching Source Code
sect1.para: This section describes how to patch an upstream project. We use the same project as shown in .
Patching a project can have different reasons:

listitem.para: Inappropriate write permission in the upstream project.

In most cases, you probably cannot commit changes directly. If you send your changes to the upstream project, it can be integrated later than you need it or it can be rejected for different reasons. To be independant of any release cycle, code styleguide, or personal issues, patch files allow to modify the source code without touching the original source.
Applying security and bug fixes and other inconveniences which are not yet available in the upstream project.
Changing the source code in way to make it build on &obsa;.
Improving security and traceability.
A pristine source code in &obsa; is easier to check for changes than a modified one. The check is usually done with a checksum (MD5 or SHA).
Improve structure and consistency.

From an organisational point of view, it is better if the changes are separated from the source code. With the changes inside the patch file, everybody is able to see what was changed and to which file it applies.

sect1.title: Branching a Project
sect1.para: This section describe how to collaborate with other projects. A branch in &obsa; terms is a personal copy of another project that lives on your home project. To be precise, all branches will be stored in a subproject of your home and named as &obsbranch1;.
Branching a project has usually the following reasons:

listitem.para: Allows you to make make changes without affecting the original project.
Apply changes in your branch to try out a different path of development.
Modify the source code, build it, try it out, and submit back your changes to the original project.

sect1.para: User &obsuser2; has finished the task now and the submit request is assigned to &obsuser1; as a number (for example, 246). User &obsuser1; can decide:

formalpara.title: Accept the Submit Request
formalpara.para: The changes from user &obsuser2; will be integrated into the &obshome1; project. The accepted submit request will be closed. Further changes need to create a new submit request.

formalpara.title: Decline the Submit Request
formalpara.para: The changes from user &obsuser2; are not integrated into the &obshome1; project. For example, the reasons to decline a submit request are usually build errors, style issues, or other problems. Usually, the declined submit request contains a message which contains the reason. Corrections has to be done in a new submit request by superseding the old one.

sect1.title: Installing Packages from &obsa;
sect1.para: &obsa; provides a place which contains all the distributions and architectures of your successfully built packages. When you create a package in your &obsa; home project, all successfully built packages will appear under the &obsdnlurlhome1; URL.

For example, if you have enabled the openSUSE Tumbleweed distribution, all packages for Tumbleweed will appear under the URL &obsdnlurlhome1;/openSUSE_Tumbleweed. This download repository is used as a installation source for Zypper or &yast;.
To install the &gitproject; from your home project, use the following steps:
